subject: RE: [junit] Re: JavaDocs
msgSnippet: You have to make a distinction between public and private level methods.. Personally I javadoc my public methods as these will be visible outside the class
messageBody:
You have to make a distinction between public and private level methods..
Personally I javadoc my public methods as these will be visible outside the
class (maybe without hte source being visible).

I sort of agree with the idea that that tests can be used to document
methods but have these problems with that:
1. Tests do not explain the methods, merely give examples of use.
2. Tests do show intention of the method, just the implementation (we're
back to the "the implementation is not the design argument").

Because of these problems I dont rely on them for documentation (if you have
any resolutions to these, I'd like to hear)

On a side note, I do use tests to enforce the contract of interfaces, which
I guess complements the documentation..

joe

> Shane Duan wrote:
>
> > The method summary, I would say. This is true especially when I was
> > studying JDK 1.4 and try to learn the new classes.
> >
>
> Fair enough. Some of the method-level JavaDoc comments in
> the JDK are pretty good. Then again, it's very heavily used
> and not subject to a lot of
> change.
>
> In general, I find most method-level JavaDoc to be
> superfluous at best, and inaccurate at the worst. It's easy
> to forget to update them, so often
> they lie. If I have to add a lot of comments to the method
> to express its intent, then it's probably doing more than it
> should or not well named.
> Tests don't lie, so I'm inclined to look at any existing
> tests to determine how a method is really intended to behave.
> I typically use JavaDoc
> simply to look up a method signature, which can easily be
> kept in synch with the code using an automated build process.
>
> Mike
